issues.title: tests/host1x: gr2d-context: Move BO address and trigger setup to exec…
issues.body:
In order to avoid use-after-free, kernel driver would reset address and
trigger registers prior to each jobs submission. So we have to adapt gr2d
context switching test accordingly.

Merge pull request #55 from digetx/3d-init-correction

libhost1x: correct 3d initialization

One register is mixed up, this fixes rendering if kernel driver resets
all registers state to 0x0 on context initialization.

Merge pull request #54 from digetx/gles1-build-fix

tests/gles1: fix compilation with newer mesa

tests/gles1: fix compilation with newer mesa

Recent mesa update broke GLES1 tests compilation, seems mesa's GLES includes
got some cleanup and 'GLchar' isn't provided by default anymore, glext.h
should be included explicitly. The offending type is defined in unused
function prototype, let's remove it to fix the issue and some others for
cleanup.

../tests/gles1/common.h:78:44: error: unknown type name 'GLchar'
 GLuint glsl_shader_load(GLenum type, const GLchar *lines[], size_t count);

Merge pull request #52 from kusma/fixup-libwrap

Fixup meson + libwrap

meson: fix librnn-support

The old support was just broken, so let's fix it.

meson: avoid _FILE_OFFSET_BITS

Meson always sets _FILE_OFFSET_BITS to 64, which replace references
to open with open64. However, this also renames *our* open-symbol to
open64, which breaks things.

Merge pull request #51 from digetx/gr2d-cleanup

GR2D cleanup

libhost1x: remove EXTEND commands from GR2D

These commands are forbidden by a HW firewall on newer Tegra's and they
will be forbidden by a software firewall too. They are pointless as well.

libhost1x: remove GR2D reset

There is no need to reset GR2D because we are re-initializing HW for each
operation and that reset definitely doesn't touch all of registers, it also
ignores SB mode.

Merge pull request #49 from digetx/gr2d-ctx-test

GR2D context switching test

tests/host1x: add test for gr2d context switching

Test draws several overlapping rectangles, each in a new context. At first
contexts are prepared and then executed, so on each execution context would be
switched, in the end the drawn result is verified and a message with a result
is printed.

libhost1x: support BO import / export

Implement BO import /export hooks for DRM, it would be used for testing GR2D
context switching.

Merge pull request #45 from kusma/meson

add meson build system

add meson build system

Meson is quite a bit faster than Autotools, which seems like a good
reason to try this out:

Full rebuild, autotools:
> real 300.18
> user 235.32
> sys 32.37

Full rebuild, meson:
> real 46.92
> user 70.71
> sys 11.24

The time above is the time './configure && make', and
'meson . build && ninja -C build' took on my Toshiba AC100, measured
using '/usr/bin/time -p'.

So, less than a sixth of the time for a full rebuild, which is very
neat. However, it's on partial rebuilds that it really shines:

Partial rebuild, autotools:
> real 30.60
> user 21.07
> sys 4.27

Partial rebuild, meson:
> real 2.27
> user 1.92
> sys 0.27

In this case, I touched src/libhost1x/host1x-gr3d.c, and rebuilt
with 'make' and 'ninja' respectively. And the result is pretty
awesome, dropping to below a tenth of the build-time.

libgrate: rename lexer/parser sources

This seems to be a bit more traditional naming for these files, and
will make it a bit easier to create implicit rules for etc.

cgc: drop pointless version-query

The version number has been 0.0.0 the whole time, and it's rather
unlikely that we'll ever make real releases from grate. So let's
get rid of this pretty pointless query.

disambiguate gles-info programs

Having two programs with the same name is a bit confusing, and some
tools have issues with it.
sort gitignore
libhost1x: add forgotten ifdef

Dump raw data in asmtool

Merge pull request #42 from digetx/minimize-3d-initializtion

libhost1x: minimize 3d registers initialization

tools/assembler: dump raw data of compiled streams

Compiled commands streams would be printed to the std output. Carrying the
whole asm parser from grate to opentegra isn't an option, we may use grate's
asm tool to generate raw arrays of commands that could be cut-and-pasted to
opentegra for a use. And of course that feature could be helpful with the
debugging of the asm-parser.

libhost1x: minimize 3d registers initialization

There are a lot of redundant stuff in the 3d initialization routine, let's
get rid of it. Note that vertex/linker/fragment program cleanup with NOP's
has been removed from the 3d initialization routine because I think it is
not needed since a proper program that doesn't rely on a initial state would
be loaded anyway.

libhost1x: add a dummy host1x implementation

It might be useful to have an ability to run grate tools in a non-native
environment, like assembler tool for example. Let's add a dummy host1x
implementation that would be used when DRM and NVHOST aren't present.

Merge pull request #41 from digetx/master

libhost1x: setup display framebuffer offset

libhost1x: setup display framebuffer offset

This fixes tests/host1x displaying garbage at the bottom, it caused by commit
4b0ef36 (setup BO guard on both sides) that prepends BO with a guard, guard
is enabled by default globally, but disabled for grate tests by default, so
the garbage is also displayed by grate tests if guard is enabled (-g option).

Merge pull request #40 from grate-driver/readme

Add a brief description about grate.

Merge pull request #38 from kusma/fix-nvhost-write

libwrap: restore memory-copying

Merge pull request #37 from kusma/simplify-commands

cleanup command stream

libwrap: restore memory-copying

In order to peek into command-buffers etc without re-mapping them,
which can interfere with the user-space driver, we actually need to
do this.

This effectively reverts ca52e7b, and adds some spewing instead when
we try to write outside...

grate: factor out program-resetting

We know what these commands do, so let's facor them out properly.

libhost1x: correct swapped ARGB / ABGR formats in host1x_gr2d_surface_blit()

This doesn't affect any of the grate tests.

tools/assembler: restrict framebuffer size to 256x256

The expected tests values are predefined for the 256x256 framebuffer, the
tests failed in case of X11 display output as it overrides the default
window width/height.

libhost1x: setup BO guard on both sides

The HW may write to memory in a backward direction, like in a case of a flipped
surface blit. Placing a guard behind a BO will sanitize that case.

libhost1x: add missed BO offsetting to host1x_gr2d_surface_blit()

The dstba and srcba needs to be adjusted as well, otherwise the blit src/dst
coordinates are (0,0).

libhost1x: correct FLOAT_TO_FIXED macros

Correct negative values and values with integer part != 0 conversion to s2.7
and s1.7. Grate is not affected by it, so this is a minor correction.
grate: use IMM-writes to VP_UPLOAD_CONST_ID

Merge pull request #36 from digetx/master

STORE opcode and fancier egl-x11-clear

grate: fragment asm/disasm: Data Write STORE opcode

Add a STORE opcode that writes row registers or stencil data to the destination
render target.

EXEC
	DW:	store rt1, r2, r3
;

EXEC
	DW:	store rt15, r0, r1
;

EXEC
	DW:	store stencil
;

tests/gles2: make egl-x11-clear fancier

Shimmer colors instead of static black.

Merge pull request #35 from digetx/master

Pixbuf BO guard
grate: fix segfaulting on invalid cmdline option

grate: disable pixbuf guard by default

It could be enabled via new grate cmdline option "-g" or "--guard".

libhost1x: correct tiled pixbuf BO size

The tile size is 16x16 pixels, so the height needs to be aligned to 16. That
fixes pixbufs BO guard area smashing.

detect writes past pixbufs BO

Add a guard area filled with a pattern to the end of a BO and after GR2D/GR3D
operation completion check that pattern persists. If pattern was overwritten,
error message is printed and execution aborts.

Merge pull request #34 from digetx/master

Stencil buffer support and some more
grate: sync tgr_3d.xml.h (prepend defines with TGR3D_)

grate: move grate->hw enums mapping to 3d-ctx

No functional change, just refactoring.

grate: use unique values for the 3d-ctx enums

C doesn't perform type checking of enums, so it is easy to make a mistake.
I did it once and it took me awhile to find out what's wrong. Unique enums will
help a bit.

tests/grate: add stencil test

Firstly, perform some basic stencil func-op checks and lastly display
"Stencil works works!" text using *late* stencil test.

grate: stencil test support

For some unknown reason there is a stencil buffer distortion on a stencil write
if a linear layout is used for the stencil buffer, while tiled works fine.
The grate-3d stencil setup takes into account the fragment discard, so both
early and late stencil buffer writes are performed as expected.

grate: fragment asm: take a note of fragment discard

That information is needed to disable early depth/stencil write if fragment might
be discarded by the program.

grate: font: specify render target for grate_3d_printf()

A render target other than display framebuffer will be used by grate/stencil test.
libhost1x: handle all Bpp's in host1x_gr2d_clear_rect()

grate: add "singlebuffered" cmdline argument

Single-buffered output is useful for FPS measure as it is not bounded by display refresh rate.

tests/gles2: add gles-stencil test

That's a fork of a gles2-quad-textured2 that I used for poking stencil params.

libwrap: prepend printed hex values with 0x

My favorite calc program recognizes pasted hex only if it is prefixed with 0x.

libgrate: print the path to test.png in grate_framebuffer_save()

Every time I'm getting confused where it got saved.

tests: static linking of gles tests

Same as da633d292ff5b6f73996b029f53860fe214bbe0a

tests: add $(PNG_CFLAGS) to AM_CFLAGS

Fixes compiling with a specific libpng version.
libhost1x: add coords sanity check to host1x_gr2d[_surface]_blit

grate: handle Y flip in grate_texture_blit()

That was accidentally missed.

Merge pull request #33 from digetx/master

Make libgrate usable externally and some fixes along with it

add "needs_explicit_vsync" display parameter for x11-display

The x11-display doesn't display single-buffered grate tests as it requires explicit
framebuffer flip. Grate will perform the flip if vsync option is set (disabled by default),
now it can check whether explicit vsync is needed and force-enable the vsync option.

These functions do not exist.

libhost1x: flip x11-display output

The image produced by GR3D is flipped vertically, now GR2D can unflip it.

libhost1x: support Y flip in host1x_gr2d[_surface]_blit

Enable Y flip if destination height argument is negative.

static linking of tools and host1x-grate tests

I run in a problem with a wrong path being resolved by a dynamic library loader inside
bind-mounted directory over NFS. Don't know how to fix it correctly, static linking
is a workaround.
grate: fragment disasm: fix swapped TEX/TXB instructions

grate: add grate_bo_create_and_map() helper

The mapping is optional and skipped if map argument is NULL.
libhost1x: handle copy directions in host1x_gr2d_blit()

grate: add grate_texture_blit()

It performs copy of source texture area to destination texture with a resize if necessary.

grate: add grate_init_with_fd()

It takes DRM FD as an argument and passes to host1x_drm_open() for use.
libhost1x: handle tileness in host1x_gr2d_clear_rect()

grate: add grate_texture_clear_rect()

It uses host1x_gr2d_clear_rect().

libhost1x: add host1x_gr2d_clear_rect()

It takes position and size of a rect to be cleared.

libhost1x: partially convert HOST1X() macros to inlined functions

This fixes -Wshadow compiler warning.

grate: add "nodisplay" grate init option

Display stuff won't be created when it's not needed.
add .pc file for libgrate
add missed header files to Makefile.am
install libgrate.so and relevant headers

This fixes cross-compilation by Gentoo's crossdev.

Merge pull request #31 from digetx/master

Texture filtering support, font rendering and some fixes

grate: use booleans for the texture warp modes

That is a bit nicer than a bitmask.

tests/grate: add texture-filter test

Test minify/magnify/mipmap texture filtering modes.

grate: display text using 3d

It should be handy to display some textual information for the grate tests.
The font texture was generated by "Ultimate bitmap font generator" tool.

grate: add grate_create_texture2()

That one infers the pixbuf size from the loaded image. Will be used by grate-font.

grate: mipmap texture support

Both autogeneration and manual load of LOD levels are implemented. The autogen
uses GR2D for texture scaling.

grate: correct 3d context uniforms location check

This fixes check for ~0u value which we are getting for a requested uniform that
wasn't found.

grate: asm: fix cgc symbols uniform name

The name must be copied from the parsed result. It happened that we haven't
used two shader programs with different symbol names in one application for now.

grate: asm: destroy lexers

This resets lexers into initial state and frees previously allocated memory,
so fixes memleak.

grate: remove unneeded 'static' declarations

Probably they were cut-n-pasted by mistake.

grate: fragment asm/disasm: TEX instruction opcodes TEX/TXB

The TEX instruction now takes opcode to differentiate between LOD biased and
un-biased texture sampling. We already implement the TEX opcode, so the opcode is
just prepended to the instruction. TXB is the new opcode, it takes additional last
source-register, the LOD bias.

EXEC
	TEX:	tex r2, r3, tex14, r0, r1, r2
;

EXEC
	TEX:	txb r0, r1, tex3, r0, r1, r2, r3
;

libhost1x: host1x_gr2d_surface_blit() fixes and feature

HW is now set up properly, the feature-hack is scale of RGBA8888 format support.

libhost1x: handle BO offset in GR2D and pixelbuffer

So the wrapped BO's are working correctly.

libhost1x: add host1x_bo_wrap()

It will be used by a texture mipmap generator, helps to keep code clean.

Merge pull request #30 from kusma/libwrap-no-memcpy

libwrap: do not move memory

libwrap: do not move memory

We're peeking into what the blob asks the kernel to do, not trying
to take over the job. In this case, we're probably not equipped to
do it either, as this is probably intended to be done on physical
addresses, not virtual ones.

Merge pull request #22 from digetx/master

Some fixes, cleanups and new features
replace nvhost BO raw flags with literals to avoid confusion

libhost1x: added X11 display output support

Grate tests will be display in a window under DRM+Xorg now. Well most of the tests,
tests that use single buffered output will be displayed only if run with explicit
VSYNC (-v option); that could be improved later if needed.

libhost1x: add host1x_gr2d_surface_blit()

It can perform surface scaling and surface format conversion. It was supposed
to do rgba -> bgra conversion, unfortunately it cannot do it. I decided to keep it,
maybe will be useful later.

libhost1x: align tiled framebuffer pitch to 256 bytes

2D HW blitter requires 256 bytes align, fixes 720 pixels wide blit.

libhost1x: use pixbuf provided pitch everywhere

Till now they happened to match, but won't after further commit.
configure.ac: make GLES tests an enableable feature

tests/grate: do not depend on implicit frame limit

In grate tests performing animation, the animation speed depends on the display

Which simply returns time elapsed since the start of profiling. It will be used

tests/gles: fix gcc 6+ compilation warning

gles-tex-combiners.c:41:22: warning: ‘texcoords’ defined but not used

Since warnings are treated as errors with a default configure, it also fixes the building.

grate: fix grate_framebuffer_save() for double buffered tests

Framebuffers swap happens before the saving, so a yet empty (swapped) buffer got saved.

tests/grate: rotate second cube too in cube-textured2 test

It was intended to rotate. Also centre cubes along X axis to make rotation

tests/grate: correct comment in the cube2_grate_fs.txt

The discard logic was inverted in the comment.

Merge pull request #21 from digetx/master

Initial textures support in the fragment asm and couple other changes

tests/grate: add cube-textured2 test

A bit more fancy variant of cube-textured test that doesn't use BLOBs
shader compiler and uses new TEX asm instruction.

grate: fragment asm: ALU rD should be disabled when omitted

For brevity rD could be omitted from ALU instruction, it should be disabled
then and that was missed.

grate: fragment asm: change ALU syntax a tad

Prepend "ALU:" to the ALU's instructions block, making syntax more flexible.
Now ALUx could be omitted for brevity, it will be treated as NOP.

EXEC
	ALU:
		ALU0:	MAD  lp.lh,  #1,         #0,         #0,         #1
		ALU1:	MAD  lp.lh,  #1,         #0,         #0,         #1
		ALU2:	MAD  lp.lh,  #1,         #0,         #0,         #1
		ALU3:	MAD  lp.lh,  #1,         #0,         #0,         #1
	ALU:
		ALU0:	MAD  r2.l*,  r3,         r2,         #0,         #1
		ALU1:	MAD  r2.*h,  r1,         r7,         #0,         #1
		ALU3:	MAD  r3.*h,  r6,         r4,         #0,         #1
	ALU:
		ALU0:	NOP
		ALU2:	MAD  r3.l*,  r5,         r0,         #0,         #1
;

grate: fragment asm/disasm: initial texture instruction support

Basic texture sampling works, no LOD yet.

TEX:	r2, r3, tex0, r0, r1, r2

grate: asm: single-line comment support

Handy to have it.

grate: fragment disasm: correct MFU mul const 1.0 register name

It should be #1 as expected by assembler.

Merge pull request #20 from digetx/master

MFU mul's and other syntax updates
grate: fix float_to_fp20(0.0f) resulting in 2.0 fp20

grate: fragment asm/disasm: MFU MUL's and updated syntax

Before:

	MFU:	var unk(0x104E51BA0) t0.fp20, t0.fp20, t0.fp20, t0.fp20

After:

	MFU:	sfu: rcp r4
		mul0: bar, sfu, bar0
		mul1: bar, sfu, bar1
		ipl: t0.fp20, t0.fp20, t0.fp20, t0.fp20

grate: linker asm/disasm: new (z) modifier

Used to pass .z position components to the fragment program.

LINK fp20, NOP, NOP, NOP, tram0.wxxx, export0 (z)

grate: fragment asm/disasm: parse MFU fetch saturation modifiers in all cases

In order to fetch .z component, saturation should be applied to NOP'ed argument.

	MFU:	fetch: NOP, NOP, NOP, sat(NOP)

grate: fragment disasm: change MFU scalar argument name "v" -> "r"

The assembler expects it to be named as "r". This just got unnoticed for a while.

Merge pull request #17 from kusma/cgc-cleanups

Cgc cleanups

libcgc: mark pointers as pointers

These are clearly pointers, as they keep moving around when the
heap moves. So let's mark them as such.
libcgc: factor out hexdumping

libwrap: use printf to print pointers

This code wrote bogus pointers for me. I'm guessing it's some
attempt at avoiding calling libc in fundamental functions, but it
looks like it just got tripped over by libc itself (probably
stdio-buffering, through puts).

Any way, this should be no less of a problem in malloc than it is
in free, so let's just ignore the problem and use printf. Seems
to work just fine to me...

libwrap: fix malloc/free wrappers

I don't quite know why, but these just crashed deep inside libc
for me. But this is needlessly involved, let's just use the
glibc-builtins for this instead. Which has the addede benefit of
working for me ;)

Merge pull request #16 from kusma/fixup-crashes

revert bad parts of 65442a10

revert bad parts of 65442a10

The for-loops in these functions depend on being able to calculate
-1 for the no-op cases.

Fixes crashes for me.

Merge pull request #14 from kusma/cull-flags-v3

grate: consolidate cull-flags

grate: consolidate cull-flags

This allows us to use OpenGL semantics, and reduces the amount of
function calls a tad.

Merge pull request #13 from digetx/master

Grate 3d API, textures, refactoring and some fixes

grate: handle single buffered vsync correctly

The display plane update ("show it" call in our case) causes indirect wait
for VBLANK, since the plane update blocks until VBLANK. Simply don't invoke
overlay/display show on grate_swap_buffers() in a single buffered mode
if grate vsync option is disabled (enabled by a "-v" cmd line argument).

libhost1x: be more verbose on error

In some cases we fail silently, in others completely ignoring the failure,
so at least printing a message in case of error should be handy.

s/pb/pixbuf/ to avoid confusion with pushbuf

For better readability.

grate: refactor texture handling a bit

Texture params (LOD level, MIP filter...) now belongs to the texture object
and not to the texture target. The texture creation/loading routines factored
out from cube-textured test to grate-texture.c.

grate: s/grate_get_actual_framebuffer_pixbuf/grate_get_draw_pixbuf/

To make it sound less abstract.

libhost1x: factor out pixel buffer layout

It's more consistent to have pixel format and data layout type separated.
Should be useful in a longer run as well, once we will have to add more
tiled layouts.
tests/grate: cull back-faces for cube-textured

tests/grate: make triangle-winding consistent

This makes all triangles counter-clockwise, so we can start doing
backface culling.

grate: drop redundant FP counters reset in grate_3d_init()

The FP_UPLOAD_INST_ID_COMMON register should reset them at once.
sync envytools-generated tgr_3d.xml.h

tests: chdir to the grate dir in tests that use data/

So texture will be loaded in tests regardless of the current pwd.

tests/grate: cube-textured: print error message if texture load failed

To avoid confusion.

libhost1x: blit if pitch/tiling mismatch in host1x_pixelbuffer_load_data()

And use that feature for texture data load in cube-textured test.

grate: refactor grate_3d_ctx_create_texture

Factor out texture state and use pixel buffer.

tests/grate: return double buffering

Grate API has all necessary bits for double buffering now.

grate: refactor grate_3d_ctx_create_render_target

Replace it with grate_3d_ctx_bind_render_target(), dither state now belongs
to the target location, use pixel buffer.
grate: replace get_*_framebuffer_bo with get_actual_framebuffer_pixbuf
grate: drop grate_bo in favor of host1x_bo

libhost1x: use HW for detiling of a saved framebuffer

Use gr2d blit to detile pixel buffer.
libhost1x: make host1x_bo public
libhost1x: make host1x_gr2d/3d_*() take pixbuffer instead of framebuffer
libhost1x: make host1x_framebuffer/pixbuffer public

libhost1x: use pixel buffer depth info in host1x_gr2d_blit()

It should blit 16bit surfaces correctly now.

libhost1x: align tiled pixel buffer pitch to 16 bytes

Fixes distorted display output with non-aligned framebuffer width.

libhost1x: handle tile'ness in host1x_gr2d_blit()

Pixel buffer format carries tiling info.

grate: drop grate_format in favor of pixel_format

The non-tiled framebuffer format could be set directly now, grate_format
is unneeded intermediary.
libhost1x: make tiled display format optional

libhost1x: try to change display mode on drmModePageFlip() error

Page flip IOCTL forbids changing framebuffer format, so format needs to be
changed first.

libhost1x: provide CRTC pipe number on overlay VBLANK

VSYNC works with a non-primary CRTC.

tests/grate: cube-textured: invert texture on load

So it is not inverted and matches the opengl convention.

libhost1x: invert vertically nvhost display output

The 3d render is not inverted now, DRM does the same.

grate: support RGB565 framebuffer format

libhost1x could handle it now.

host1x: introduce pixel buffer

The intention is to use it everywhere as a universal pixel storage.

tests/grate: add cube-textured test

New build dependency - libdevil.

grate: initial texture support

Basic texture support, exposed via 3d context API.
sync envytools-generated tgr_3d.xml.h

grate: add 3d context API

Get rid of hardcoded 3d context params. It should be much easier now to
implement textures and other goodies. Double buffered display output is gone
from grate tests for now, while single got fixed.

Sync envytools-generated tgr_3d.xml.h

grate: factor out 2d related functions to grate-2d.c

Logical split, no functional change.

grate: factor out 3d related functions to grate-3d.c

Logical split, no functional change.

libwrap: fix argument-less ioctl call

The _IOC_SIZE() macro doesn't represent the presence of an argument. There is
always an argument, even when it is absent, i.e. NULL.

grate: derive asm related functions from shader-cgc.c to grate-asm.c

The shader-cgc got bloated too much, it's easier to navigate the separate files.

partial type conversion cleanup

I have been bitten several times by it and decided to cleanup, so we
could have -Wconversion in CFLAGS . Unfortunately, it's just too many
places to fix, I gave up.

grate: add grate_3d_*() helpers

It is more readable now. Start to use envytools-generated header.

tests/grate: provide linker asm for the tests

That's more consistent and now we can drop the hardcoded linker code from
the grate_draw_elements().

import tgr_3d header generated by enytools

The plan is to use as the source of registers and bitfields literals.

libcgc: compile all sources unconditionally

Provide BLOB stubs instead of the libcgc's.

Merge pull request #10 from kusma/cgshader

add GL_EXT_Cg_shader example

Merge pull request #12 from digetx/master

Display support for nvhost, libwrap works under root and minor refactoring

libwrap: try "/dev/knvmap" as well

BLOB uses "/dev/knvmap" instead of "/dev/nvmap" under root.

libhost1x: implement display output for nvhost

The grate tests now will be displayed with the downstream video driver.

tools: compile cgc unconditionally

libcgc is always available now, kinda useful for a compile-testing without
the BLOB.

tools: move grate assembler test executor to tools

The assembler tests runner is more like a tool now, so it's more logical to
have it in tools.

grate: disasm: silence the "warning: Value stored to 'buf' is never read"

Fixes clang-analyzer warnings.

grate: move cgc stubs to libcgc

This allows to compile and use assembler without the BLOB being available
in the system.

Merge pull request #11 from digetx/master

TRAM swizzle fix, ALU KILL register + minor stuff

tests/grate: asm: improve the vertex branching test a bit

Should be more robust now.

tests/grate: assembler: Allow to run standalone code, decouple the tests

The assembler test is able to run standalone asm tests now.

Example:

./assembler --vs asm/vs.txt --fs asm/fs.txt --lnk asm/linker.txt

Will compile the asm's, print the disassembly and show the rendered result.

grate: linker asm: fix the mixed up TRAM swizzle

It's actually the TRAM destination swizzle, not the vertex export source.
.gitignore: add hidden files and test.png

tests/gles2: glActiveTexture() should be called before the glBindTexture()

A minor correction, it happened to work because unit 0 is active by default.

grate: fragment asm/disasm: introduce the ALU "KILL" register

Parse the "KILL" register.
add GL_EXT_Cg_shader example

Merge pull request #9 from digetx/master

Fragment asm fix + some cleanup

grate: fragment asm: fix ALU destination register bitfield

This was accidentally overlooked. Grrr...

grate: fragment asm: write to PSEQ 0x500 after the instructions

BLOB does it, so we too. Probably some kind of buffer flush?

grate: linker asm: correct the TRAM row index check in the parser

The MFU can address 16 TRAM rows maximum, so the linker too.

grate: asm: don't set yydebug in the parsers reset

So it could be controlled by an external code.

grate: asm: make yyerror a weak symbol

The tool I'm using for RE has a lame build setup and it's a quite cumbersome
to re-do it (maybe later). This is solely to make Dmitry's life a bit easier
right now, it has no effect on the grate.

grate: fragment asm: rename "FRAG_*" literals to "FRAGMNET_*"

Minor cleanup.

grate: fragment asm: change MFU var operation arguments "r%d" -> "t%d"

"t" for TRAM. Keep the "r" for other operations, since it's a row register
in case of those operations.

tests/grate: place assembler in alphabet order in Makefile.am

Just for consistency.

Merge pull request #8 from digetx/master

Fragment/lnker asm/disasm + minor fixes

grate: vertex asm: change a negate modifier from neg() to "-" sign prefix

That feels more convenient.
grate: change vertex asm/disasm license for consistency

tests/grate: make cube test draw a cube and not a triangle

Fix the number of vertices to draw.

grate: add fragment and linker asm/disasm

They are made in a way the vertex asm/disasm is, lex+yacc. Nothing fancy :)
Less hardcoded values in grate_draw_elements(), grate_program_new() now takes
one more argument, the linker .grate_shader; if it is NULL, the old-default
linker behaviour is preserved.
grate: move asm.* -> vertex_asm.* as a preparation for adding other asm's
grate: a minor vertex asm parser cleanup

libhost1x: reset gr3d hw on init

The only way to recover the hung 3D module is to reset it.

grate: write to the PSEQ register 0x501

More than one fragment pipeline execution batch works now.
grate: set PSEQ instructions number

grate: disasm: add more "consts"

Some compilers would error out on a missing "const", this makes code more
portable.
grate: asm: "asm.h" should be a local include
add a gl_LastFragData shader

Merge pull request #7 from digetx/master

Vertex assembler

grate: disasm: don't print dst-src registers for the RETs opcode

It was accidentally overlooked.

grate: asm: change address register notation A0-A3 to A0.[xyzw]

It's seems to be commonly used across the opengl specs, at least by nvidia.

grate: asm: disasm-compliant destination address register grammar

We are using A0 notation for the address register, while disasm would
print R[0-63] for a sake of debugging. Make asm syntax more permissive, so
that disasm code could be cut-n-pasted without a hassle.

libhost1x: don't fail host1x_drm_open() if display is unavailable

DRM display is not available when xorg server is running and active.
Just continue without it, so that grate tests could be run under xorg.
Rendering result will be saved to the "test.png".

pull_requests.title: tests/host1x: gr2d-context: Move BO address and trigger setup to exec…
pull_requests.body:
In order to avoid use-after-free, kernel driver would reset address and
trigger registers prior to each jobs submission. So we have to adapt gr2d
context switching test accordingly.

issue_comments.body:
Hmm, interesting. I never installed grate, as it's not really useful for me installed. What was your motivation for you to install?

Perhaps libwrap should be marked as noinst? @thierryreding, what do you think?

I don't think marking libwrap as noinst will work, since that typically results in automake building it as a static library, which will prevent it from being used with LD_PRELOAD. Perhaps namespacing it as libgrate-wrap.so would work?
Ah, true. Yeah, perhaps that's better.

The goal for the trimslice is a fully open source tegra build for xorg and weston/wayland.  Still using both the main portage tree and my overlays, but it's on full mainline kernel (using gentoo-sources) and device tree u-boot.  Of all my arm machines, this one is the only one close to "fully open source"...
Looks good, thanks!
I had libhost1x excluded from compilation and hadn't noticed compilation breakage at first time, sorry :(
Looks good, thanks!
Hey, kusma!  Do you know what's the intention for download, surface blit, ctx gr2d classes?
And is generic 0x51 also doing it all?
I mean why those classes exists while there is 0x51.
I'm not quite sure what you're referring to...
For example, in tests/nvhost/gr2d.c nvhost_gr2d_init() you set class_id to 0x51 and then immediately change it to 0x52 (surface blit), why?
Ah, it was added by tagr...
I think that's just artifacts from how the init-sequence was dumped from the proprietary driver.
Ok, I also asked tagr on irc, he'll probably answer tomorrow. Do you know what download class is?
No, I don't know :/
nvhost gr2fill_test failed in my tegra QEMU'lator because I haven't implemented 0x52 cause it's intention is obscure :( for now
Aha. Is that emulator available somewhere? sounds useful!
Currently it's on my machine locally only (with backup to private repo), it's in active development state. However, probably, I can push it to github as-is. Do you want it now?
Nah, just curious. But please let me know when you decide to make it public :)

Okay.

Teaser! Opentegra driver with EXA =). 2 cores + AVP, i.e . booting through uboot/fastboot works fine. Suspend, cpuidle works also found couple kernel bugs with it, fixes submitted upstream.
![q11](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1242749/5893300/52a67134-a4ef-11e4-840b-23b6dce8b019.jpeg)
Good call, thanks!
Oooh, super-sweet :)
Yeah, it's a bobby dazzler! Very convenient for debugging and RE. I'm planning to start adding gr3d support soon, currently looking around and examining grate code/wiki =).

I don't think I've done enough REing for it to be possible to do gr3d properly, I currently don't understand the linking-programs located on offset 0x300 and upwards (and it seems 0xe20 and 0xe21 somehow also plays a role). 0x300 seems to be a program that copies from the output buffer of the vertex shader into the TRAM (triangle ram) for the rasterizer/fragment shader to consume, but I haven't figured out it's ISA yet.
It shouldn't be a problem, you know :) But I need to get big picture of how it all works first!
0x300 is even instr halve, 0x301 odd, and etc
Yeah, I noted that on https://github.com/grate-driver/grate/wiki/Shader-Linking
(I did see clear patterns in every second dword)

0xe20 and 0xe21 is some set of pixel/raster and triangle attrs. I'll be able to tell exactly what it is once will reach that point in development of it or just ping me if you decide to become dirty =)
Do you know if it is possible to run egl with nvhost and without downstream tegra xorg driver?
@digetx: Not that I know. I have two setups myself, one running the downstream kernel, and one running the upstream kernel.

Oh, the xorg-driver, not the kernel-driver. I guess my answer is still no, but I mostly run tests using a pbuffer-context from a console. But I do need the x-server running, and to set DISPLAY to ":0", so I don't actually have to deal with all the rendering-bugs...
Oh, and I poked around a bit more tonight, and think I got somewhere with the 0x3xx registers, see https://github.com/grate-driver/grate/wiki/Shader-Linking for the details.
I have that setup in qemu too now, but I get only black and gray screen since gr3d isn't implemented. So, egl is also working from console? I'm trying it now...
You'll RE it quicker than I'll figure out what it all means from comments to those regs =)
Use of "DISPLAY=:0" works fine, thanks! I reached indirect write from host1x module (to gr3d), which I haven't implemented yet, but it's trivial =)
Fixed.
I'll try to re-do it in a cleaner way.
What was the problem with this approach?
FWIW, this looks reasonable (and more importantly, correct) to me.

I just started to move geometry load to a separate file (and was going to do it with the rest of the stuff) to make working with code a bit easier and decided that this change might become unnecessary.

But cleanup turned out to be a bit complicated, might return to it later. So re-opening.
Merged, thanks :)

Great! 👍
I think it's time for the fragment shader, should be even more fun!
Yeah, the fragment shader really need some low-level peeking to figure out the timing etc :)

I don't think that it uses delay slots or whatever timing constraints, should be couple staggered ALU's as described in the patents. I hope we could getaway with some bare minimum :) The good thing that there are much more public nvidia patents on the fragment shader pipeline than on vertex and they seems to be a bit useful, at least giving some insight.

BTW,  you haven't answered regarding the asm syntax description. I think a wiki page should be good enough, I'll add it once will get too tired of the fragment stuff :) Anyway, syntax should be quite obvious by looking at the asm test samples, it was partially inspired by the freedreno's asm.
@digetx: A wiki page for the ASM syntax description would be nice, yeah :)
Awesome stuff!
Heh, missed "i" in the linker three times, my keyboard needs a fix.
Nice!
Nice!
I think it's good enough. We can fix the render later if will be necessary.
I forgot to say, very nice work! My nits are very minor, and I really like the result :)
Thank you a lot for looking though the code! I'll add patches to this series addressing the comments.
I really look forward to getting the cube-texture example transitioned to ASM-shaders, and we'll finally have a fully functional, blob-free, meaningful 3d example :)
That should be easy now. For a really meaningful example we will need to add a depth buffer, because now the rendered cube is missing sides :)
Yeah. Or just enable backface culling ;)
I tried, doesn't help :/ But maybe I missed something.
Hmm, seems culling doesn't really work. Either that, or we've messed up the vertex-order. I'll have a look.
I added patches addressing the comments and couple more, please take a look. Also swapped texcoords in your "triangle-winding" commit, so cw sides are not inverted horizontally.
Nice!
Great, thank you! I already merged envytools.
Apart from the detail above, I think this is pretty nice :)

Ah, sorry about that!

The disasm in libcgc is a bit outdated, maybe we should re-use the disasm from libgrate for blob-generated disassembly? Or move it to libcgc? Or you have some other plan on it?

I don't have a strong opinion, since I'm mostly using my tool + QEMU for looking at what assembly BLOB emits.
I corrected "libhost1x: add host1x_bo_flush()" commit a bit and and added couple minor updates for  	tools/assembler. Will do something about fragment uniforms ASAP 🤒

Yeah, I think moving to your disasm for blob-generated disassembly would be a better move. I don't care much how it's done ;)

I still want to figure out a bit more about the data-structures that the blob-compiler uses. Our libcgc-stuff is pretty hacky in figuring out where the binary code is etc. I have a feeling there's some more sane C-ism to it.
More stuff from BLOB would be good to have. It should store fragment texture samplers locations somewhere there.
Yeah, and swizzles for linking texture sampler-inputs
Very good! Everything looks fine to me.

I squashed "grate: refactor grate_3d_ctx_set_fragment_uniform*()" and "grate: fragment asm: support uniforms" to "grate: support fragment uniforms". We are now use BLOB's symbol location encoding for fragment uniforms, so setting fragment uniform also works for cgc shaders. It is very similar to vertex uniforms, the difference is that BLOB supports only one type of fragment uniform - a vector and it's components enable mask. So a float uniform is a vector with 1 component enabled and mat4 is represented as four vec4's. Please take a look :)
Looks good 👍

Maybe we should build two variants of libwrap? One with all hexdumps and BLOB malloc's/IOCTL tracing enabled and the other just envytools registers tracing. That solves build coverage and produces less noise when you just want to look at registers IO.
While that's not a bad idea, I'm not sure it's really worth the hassle... The malloc/ioctl-tracing is pretty rarely used these days, at least by me.
I don't mind.
Great stuff :)
Looks correct 👍
This is just a quick follow-up to the previous PR
Neat!
BTW, seems perspective projection matrix is not correct. Cube gets skewed when drawn at the side of a screen (widescreen aspect). Just a note, I may check the mat a bit later.
making a game? ;)
Looks good :)
Shouldn't take much effort to turn it into some trivial game eventually, but.... meeeh. Not a gamer :P
Yeah, a graceful error handling is always a good thing to do 👍
I forgot to mention that cube-textured2 and interactive tests should work without CgDrv, aren't they?
@digetx: Yeah, they do. I just wanted to be consistent in terms of API usage :)
Good catch 👍
Re-spun, now with the TXB opcode. Please take a look =)
Changed the names, please take a look. 🔍 :)
Consolidated log2_size() and switched to clz.

You are too fast! I was going to write that I shouldn't have removed the grate_texture_set_max_lod() :)

Will re-add it.
I didn't pull yet!
Ah nice :) Will fix now then.
Factored out grate_create_texture2() addition to a standalone commit and added test4_max_lod() to texture-filter test. Should be good now :)
Great stuff :)
I noticed couple issues, will re-open once they are fixed.
Updated the patchset, please take a look.
Awesome! 😺

The naming here seems a bit confused to me... ["guard band"](http://developer.download.nvidia.com/assets/gamedev/docs/Guard_Band_Clipping.pdf) is already used as a term in 3D renderering, but not for something like this...
Okay, I'll drop the "band".
Dropped ;)
So?

Sorry, I kind of forgot about this one. I'm not crazy about it as-is... it seems like useful debugging functionality, but I'm not so sure about it being on always. Wouldn't it be OK to make it opt-in instead?
Should be OK, I'll add grate cmdline option.
Added the cmdline option.
Thank you ;)
Hmm, I get an undefined symbol about `sinf@GLIBC_2.4` in egl-x11-clear after this change...  I need to link with `-lm` on my setup...
Oh, good catch. I only compiled-tested it with the latest build environment which haven't complained about it, will fix it shortly.
Added -lm, compiles fine on 12.04 now ;)
Unfortunately stencil test breaks without the magic init. Comment out `grate_wait_for_key` from the stenci.c and run `while :; do ./stencil -f || break; done`. Seems you removed too much :)
@digetx: Aha, interesting. I'll rework this later, then :)
@digetx: OK, dropped the code-removal in favor of just moving and naming things a bit more.

I've tested the case that crashed for me before `LD_PRELOAD=libwrap/.libs/libgrate-wrap.so.0.0.0 DISPLAY=:0 tests/gles2/gles-quad-textured2 -w 500 -h 500 --min GL_LINEAR_MIPMAP_NEAREST > /dev/null` and it indeed doesn't crash with this patch, however there are `BUG: writing outside buffer!` messages, is it okay?

@digetx: Yeah. My understanding is that this is when the application calls the kernel-driver with incorrect parameters, and there's such a case in the GLES-driver. I'm not entirely sure what happens in the blob-case, apart from it not crashing...
Valgrind complains about all IOCTL's that it's not aware of. Probably it is not the only one it complains about, isn't it?
@digetx: Somehow doesn't seems like it. I'm not really sure, but this made this go away. I don't really care though, so if you don't like this, let's drop it.

@kusma I have checked it on my side, indeed this is the first IOCTL which valgrind complains about. After applying your patch, valgrind complains about TEGRA_DC_EXT_SET_NVMAP_FD and so on. So yeah, not much sense in suppressing only one IOCTL of many.
I'm pretty sure you should get the same result as me.
I might have scanned the output too quickly. In either case, let's drop this.

I just re-tested this patch with updated grate's kernel that has memory "securing" enabled and it shows that memory fetching happens regardless of the texture dimensions.

`tegra20-mc 7000f000.memory-controller: MC_DECERR (0x0000001b): 0x6ed5e900 csr_texsrd (read )`
Ah, actually it's not securing but just some invalid memory address.
I even haven't tested it properly before :P

The only things I know of that this is lacking compared to the autotools-system is:
- Generating pkgonfig-files. This is [not very hard to do](http://mesonbuild.com/Pkg-config-files.html), but I'm not very convinced it's really nessecary. @digetx, you added the pkgconfig-file generation initially... what do you use it for?
- The ability to opt-out of building GLES-tests. Since meson is so much faster, I didn't feel like this was nessecary to support. It also wouldn't be the hardest thing ever to add if needed.

I'm also not (yet?) proposing we remove the automake-files. I'd rather we test this out a bit in-tree before we do something drastic ;)

I was experimenting with using libgrate for opentegra and haven't used pkgconfig since then, yeah it is not really needed.

Ninja is indeed much faster than automake, but it's not a problem for me since I'm crosscompiling.  I'll probably continue to use autotools, so have no objections ;) I made a test build with meson, works fine 👍
@digetx: Yeah, after trying and failing a bit to try to get a workable cross-compiling setup, I decided to just try to make my existing workflow better instead ;)

@digetx: updated with some cleanups:
- fixed the typo you pointed out (tests -> tools etc)
- switched to implicit rules for parsers/lexers

To do the latter, I had to rename the sources. It's a bit boring, but matching artifact-names and source names seems reasonable to me, so whatever ;)

@digetx: Good call, fixed.

I get the warning when building with meson. I believe meson use a bigger set of default warnings than autotools, perhaps that's why?
@kusma same applies to mesa as well.
Nice catch!
@digetx: I've patched my latest mesa-branch for this problem, thanks!
@kusma Awesome :-)

review_comments.body:
Hmm, I'm not loving mixing the tiling into the pixel format, as those are completely orthogonal features... Tiling is the order the pixels are stored, whereas the pixel format is the order the components of the pixels are stored. IIRC, the hardware even tiles on byte-sizes, as opposed to pixel-sizes.

I think we should instead have an `enum pixel_layout { PIX_BUF_LAYOUT_LINEAR = 0, PIX_BUF_LAYOUT_TILED = 1 }` or something.

review_comments.body: These should probably use `PIXEL_FORMAT_RGB565` etc from the rnndb-generated header, no?
This is a small nit, but "actual" sounds a bit too abstract to me. How about using OpenGL terms (draw-buffer), and say `grate_get_draw_pixbuf` instead?
If we want to play by OpenGL-rules, dithering is not a render-target state, but a general render-state; switching render-target keeps the current dither-state.

While this is the way OpenGL used to do things like this, bindless is now the new wine, where the texture object is specified directly. And especially for a low-level API, I think the following makes a lot more sense; perhaps we make it up to the callee to keep track of what object they want to modify (e.g pass `struct grate_texture *` to these functions instead of `struct grate_3d_ctx *`)? That would surely lead to less boiler-plate code...
It is GCC extension, works fine in the UNIX world. https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc-4.6.4/gcc/Conditionals.html

Sounds good to me, no objections.

I'd print a error message and abort on unexpected "default:", that will avoid stupidity.

As I said before, it should be better to move all context params checks/mappings to the grate-3d-ctx.c, but that should be another patch. I think the current variant is good enough.
Yeah, that was my reasoning as well; this move can come later 👍
And yeah, I guess it would make sense to print (or just assert) in default instead.

This seems like you're setting up a symobol per scalar value. Is that so? If so, I don't think it's a great idea.

I think it'd be better if we used the types already defined in glsl_type, and augmented it with a precision-value. We could use location to device between GRATE_TYPE_FX10_LOW and GRATE_TYPE_FX10_HIGH, by requiring GRATE_TYPE_FP20 to be aligned to multiples of two, and letting the last bit of location as a differentiator for FX10...
By the way, it'd be totally fine to just support GLSL_TYPE_FLOAT as a first approach.
And we might not want to keep the GLSL-prefixes here. There's no point in differentiating between GLSL-types and other types. IMO...

The reason why I care about this, is that I don't want combinatory explosion here. Types like this explode very quickly...

In fact, we might want to have something like vector/matrix-sizes... Hmm, dunno, maybe I'm over-thinking this now...
Thank you very much for the suggestions. BLOB seems encode fragment uniform type-position in the symbol location, maybe we can re-use it. However, the type enum seem differ from the vertex uniforms.

Hmm, this looks like we need the transpose of what something like [GLM would produce](https://github.com/g-truc/glm/blob/e8962dda2a2652a6a97432449681a4366876fc84/glm/gtc/matrix_transform.inl#L274)... Perhaps we should just switch to using GLM for the computations, and make our upload-code transpose instead (or perform matrix multiplications the other way around in the shader)?

We are using column-major notation for the mats, but perspective matrix was defined as row-major (transposed).

I'm not familiar with GLM, looks like its perspective matrix is same OpenGL-standard we had (row-major). What would be the benefits of switching to GLM? Seems it's C++ only.
Well, column-major is the standard OpenGL mat, not row-major.

My thought was that it has kind of become the canonical OpenGL matrix library. But it being C++ is probably a show-stopper for that, didn't think of that. But I'm a bit confused that this doen't seem to match what GLM does. `Result[3][2]` seems like i would match `.wz`, not `.zw`...
Also column-major vs row-major is kind of irrelevant here, it's a notation-thing, not a memory-layout thing. The relevant information is row-vectors vs column-vectors.

Yeah, I think we've just doing the wrong memory-layout for all of our matrices.

https://github.com/digetx/grate/blob/7ff314d7b7aa37a69a425232f1089a87463f218a/src/libgrate/matrix.c#L72

This corresponds to the fourth float:

https://github.com/digetx/grate/blob/7ff314d7b7aa37a69a425232f1089a87463f218a/src/libgrate/matrix.h#L29

However, it should be the twelfth float:

https://github.com/mesa3d/mesa/blob/master/src/mesa/math/m_matrix.c#L1098
At least this change makes us consistently wrong, so let's do this, and flip the matrices later (we can just change the order of the named components and update the shader-code accordingly, I guess).
It's column-major notation. What's wrong about it? :) GLSL uses column-major notation.

Row-major vs column-major only matters when you write matrices mathematically, it doesn't dictate the memory-layout of the matrix. It's a notation-thing, not a memory-layout thing.

An GLSL supports both column-vectors *and* row-vectors, you can do `mat4 * vec4` or `vec4 * mat4`, and they do different operations.
Scratch it, I'll re-check it once more. Row-major vs column-major is annoying.
Yeah, you are right. So finally, we are using row-major notation in grate right now to define mats. But the de facto standard in OpenGL is column-major.

And what we're doing doen't seem to match column-major even if we interpret column-major as meaning memory layout (which seems to be what the OpenGL specification and [Wikipedia claims](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Row-_and_column-major_order), so I guess that part of argument was flawed), because OpenGL 2.1 defines:

> LoadMatrix takes a pointer to a 4 × 4 matrix stored in column-major order as 16
> consecutive floating-point values, i.e. as
> a1 a5 a9 a13
> a2 a6 a10 a14
> a3 a7 a11 a15
> a4 a8 a12 a16

And:

> The arguments to
> void Translate{fd}( T x, T y, T z );
> give the coordinates of a translation vector as (x y z)^T . The resulting matrix is a translation by the specified vector:
> 1 0 0 x
> 0 1 0 y
> 0 0 1 z
> 0 0 0 1

Which shows that the matrix is intended to be the transpose of what i.e mat4_translate produces.

Also, for this particular case, the glFrustum (which is the closest thing defined in OpenGL) is defined as:

> The corresponding matrix is
> (2n) / (r−l), 0, (r+l) / (r−l), 0
> 0, (2n) / (t−b), (t+b) / (t−b), 0
> 0, 0 -(f+n) / (f−n), -(2fn) / (f−n)
> 0, 0, −1, 0

Which, according to the order defined in LoadMatrix, would mean "wz" would be the right memory location for `-2.0f * near * far / depth`.¨

Yeah. I'm fine with making things consistently row-major, though. I'd like if we could be consistent with OpenGL also, but it's less important ;)

So, let's do this as-is, and possibly change our layout later, OK?
OK! 👍

The "common" way of doing this, is to consider these two different opcodes, [TEX](http://gallium.readthedocs.io/en/latest/tgsi.html#opcode-TEX) and [TXB](http://gallium.readthedocs.io/en/latest/tgsi.html#opcode-TXB)...

Indeed, differentiating instructions by opcode should be more expressive and there will be more opcodes in the future. We should probably omit the 3-rd cubemap coord source register from the current TEX instruction and use it in the TEX2 instruction opcode (following TGSI ISA) once will add support for cubemaps. 

 I'll re-spin the series.

Ah, okay :) I just quickly glanced through the TGSI ISA without paying much attention. So the TEX opcode is fine as it is now, no need to change anything about it.
This is a huge jump-table, using compiler-specific range-based case-statements... How about just doing __builtin_clz() instead? :)

I think this function is needlessly complicated, because it seems to allow interpreting overlapping memory as wildly different things. Sure, sub-allocations will allow multiple allocations of different format/pitches inside the same BO. But those allocations will not overlap. There's some use-cases where untyped textures are used (but not on T20-class hardware, more like OpenGL 4.x hardware), but in these cases the texel-size is known (you can overlay float32 on int32 and rgba8888 etc, but not on int16 etc). Two separate sub-allocations shouldn't overlap in memory.

So, I think we can first early-out on `src_orig != dst_orig`, then on `src_orig->offset != dst_orig->offset` (different sub-allocations). Then we can assert that the sizes are the same (just in case we somehow botched a sub-allocation). After that, the rest becomes a lot easier, as we *know* that the format and pitch have to be the same. Basially, we need to do a rectangle overlap test, and finally compare the top-left points.
Yeah, we probably won't ever need such unusual sub-allocations. 👍
Probably we should rename grate_texture to grate_surface.
